Can you articulate the gap between the current state and the expected or envisioned state?


Currently the app only allows a 4 digit numeric PIN. Ideally the app would allow for a longer and more diverse (more characters) password. The app provides a lockout after several attempts however with access to the QR code, you can attempt the password as many times as you like. Based on a rudimentary attempt (human operated, little prior experience with the app, attempting to brute force, clear app storage+cache, attempt again), you could brute force the code in a matter of hours at the very worst. Assuming a capable attacker, you could likely brute force the app in a matter of minutes.
Hypothetical Scenario: Based on how easy it was to lock out and restore the app it should be trivial to operate this app in a VM and automate+duplicate the process. Imagine a handful of android VMs based off a memory snapshot of the app brute forcing a set of pins to divide the work and either reporting back upon success or restoring the VM and attempting another set of pins, rinse repeat. With just 10k combinations, around 3 attempts per lockout, and a generous 1 minute per lockout(assuming full automation of app interaction and restore), it should only take about 3400 VM-minutes to crack when rounding up to the next hundreds.
A VM on AWS capable of running Android only costs 0.0168USD an hour(fractional by the second). With this, it would only cost 0.98USD (for 1000 VMs) and about 3 minutes 30 seconds to crack.
Of course this hypothetical supposes a decently sophisticated attacker however with the scale of AWS, even mild amounts of sophistication can reduce the financial and time cost of an attack like this to almost nothing. This should be considered a cornerstone piece of our decision making infrastructure in the future. It is essential that we minimize the potential for malicious actors to compromise our voting infrastructure.
 
Potential Solutions
Solution to Brute Force: Increase the PIN size(no less than 8 and preferably up to 64 or more) and/or transform it into a standard password to allow for more character diversity.
Solution to Restore bypassing Lockout: Migrate the PIN challenge (for voting itself. don't require a PIN to view or prepare votes) to a on network operation. Pre-fund the challenge Txs with the initial registration fee and deny all Tx after the initial allocated Tx have been consumed. Refund remaining allocated funds after voting has ended.

At the moment every country or state has there own databases. There is no central worldwide database. I believed that it´s mainly because of safety and privacy issues that can be overcome using decentralized Cardano blockchain.
Travelling with pets can be a nightmare. You need a physical passport, with rabies vaccines or blood tests up to date (depends on the country), and there is not a piece of single health information in both microchip, database or passport. Being a Veterinarian I have realized the many issues related with travelling and recording health information, to be used by any Vet, in case your pet has a health problem in a different place (city or country) rather than your own clinic. Also, I have seen forged passports with false information that allow puppies to travel underage.
Nowadays, Vets lose a ton of time just writing (both physically and digitally) the medical information and all the vaccines. Imagine having 20 vaccines in one day. You have to physically remove the stamp of each one and put it in the passport and then, register the mandatory ones (usually rabies) in a digital platform and all in your own clinical software. Even if that only takes 10 minutes per client, by the end of the day you´ll spend more than 3 hours doing paperwork and not providing real veterinary care to the patients. And that time is useless for clients because when they move abroad, loose their physical passport or travel, they don´t have and own their full clinical information.
My ultimate vision is to have a platform that connects with the pet´s microchip and allows Vets, Travelling inspectors, and other institutions like shelters, etc., to have full (translated, if needed) clinical information (allergies, vaccines, surgeries, chronic or infectious diseases) and that can be used to upload new information with bar codes or any other method that can speed up all the processes. I imagine scanning the pet for the microchip, grabbing vaccine and pass it thought a bar or QR code, and automatically upload to the patient file, history and digital passport.
Keep in mind that the pandemic just made public health and preventing zoonosis (diseases that are transmitted by animals to humans), a top priority. Animals can travel and infect with many diseases and it´s crucial that we have a safe and decentralized platform to keep the thing running smoothly and that can allow traceability in case of an outburst. Also, with new species being introduced has house pets, those risks increase significantly. This can also, be used in production animals. However, they already have much better systems implemented than house pets.

Definition:
Authoritarianism is characterized by highly concentrated and centralized government power maintained by political repression and the exclusion of potential challengers. It uses political parties and mass organizations to mobilize people around the goals of the regime.
This means that Authoritarianism is the exact opposite of Decentralization.
Then the question is:
How to protect a Decentralized system against an external threat actively trying to damage it?
Let's ask some more questions:
Why the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) banned Bitcoin but most of the mining is done in China?
Will a 51% attack on Bitcoin happen one day?
Is it true that the UN and the WHO are influenced by the CCP?
Is it true that the CCP influenced federal and local elections in South Korea, Canada, Australia and others?
What the world will look like in ten years with a techno authoritarian regime as the first economy?
Why the US and European countries didn't ban Bitcoin when they could?
Is it because maybe they realized that Iranian, North Korean and Venezuelan governments were interested on using Bitcoin and crypto as a trading mechanism?
Will Russia mine Bitcoin in Siberia?
How the highest elites of the world will try to keep power?
Will these aspects clash with decentralization?
If so, what to do?
 
If Decentralization will be a trend in the upcoming years then also Authoritarianism.

Can you articulate the gap between the current state and the expected or envisioned state?


In here, there are very smart people with the best of intentions, however once Cardano gets mass adoption it will inevitably attract bad actors to the proposals and voting system.
What are the tools, systems or principles in place to avoid corruption within Catalyst?
If there are already some, then is important to share this info through the Catalyst channels.
A good example of a crack in the system is the Referral Rewards - 500 ADA is given to someone if a the winner in a fund was initially referred by a previous Cardano / Catalyst user. This reward requires trust and the worst part is that not only is corruptible but it actively attracts corruption because it has two of the common aspects of a corruption dynamic which are: hard to get, easy to cheat AND not verifiable, not punishable.
Several times 500 ADA reward lost mean that other projects would not get funded.
Not only that, after the damage is done:
Corruption works exponentially, if there are no defenses and the same mistakes are made bad actors attract more bad actors AND bad actors already abusing the system confidently exploit the breach more intensively.
Then,
Continuous or neglected corruption leads to:
Down spiral - a corruptible environment gains a reputation where bad actors can thrive
And then:
Solidification - a cultural development and appropriation that expands to other forms of culture (e.g. An individual could tell to himself "I belong here and this is what I do and it doesn't matter much because lots of others do it as well")
Worst case scenario:
Downturn - Being dishonest becomes generally more profitable giving clear disadvantages to those that follows the rules of the game. When this dynamic is mixed with the "Law of the jungle" where the strongest / biggest wins then dishonesty becomes a survival method more than a choice. At this point corruption is sustainable, expands and regenerates itself until resources are exhausted and the system dies or there is a drastic change that make individuals to be forced or inspired to be honest.

This isn't a criticism, more like a raw assessment of what Catalyst does and what it does not. I have long been familiar with IOHK / Cardano but only took some really serious deep dive (metadata and other key functionalities) during the October 2020 WyoHackaton where our little team of 2 (Len Delunas creator of the FundTrack idea, and myself helping my old friend, business colleague, crypto peer, and Cardano early adopter Len) won 3rd place. That's when I joined Project Catalyst every week, so I'm still relatively a newbie there.
I've looked at some of the projects, and found that we never emphasize enough the fact that the most substantive projects should have some serious road map to spread adoption of the Cardano ecosystem among developers, which is one major key objective for all Catalyst successive stages, if I understood correctly. From what I've seen of Catalyst with Dor every week since October 2020, the goal there is to build a community under a "collective intelligence" mechanism design, using a process of curating, evaluating, selecting projects and deciding their adequate level of financing.
From what I observed from the data more recently, those well embedded with already a strong brand value and recognized track-record inside the community (street creds as we like to say), do better. And those who slice their project idea into smaller components gradually offering these with "low-ball" figures (numbers) also do better. So while I believe that several hundred thousand USD figure (number) is a realistic SaaS product start-up stage level of "angel" financing, this may not be the level of commitment where votes are willing to go at this particular stage of Catalyst.
So in case projects realistically evaluated at several hundred k$ do not get voted, perhaps there is a plan B to propose a component of the project with a lower-ball number and build up from there, however that doesn't start to tackle the complexity and cost and duration over time of a real industrial size project. But then again I'm still a newbie in the Catalyst system, so my understanding may not be reliable. But that maybe would be my own navigation map should I submit something in future: gradual steps inside the Catalyst collective intelligence system.
But then again the immediate corollary to this is, what is representativity, what is a vote besides token-based staking, whose vote is it? There is a serious difference when you have real skin in the game, when you are experienced. When you have the kind of interpersonal maturity of social and professional judgement, and are able to appreciate and evaluate the full development, financing, and implementation trajectory of a project. Vs when you are a genuine and a good faith contributor but in fact have very little skin in the game and even less experience in socio-professional access, in substance, and in time, then again perhaps a relative notion, but still.
Because skin in the game, experience, maturity of judgement, those have a tendency to fly as a squadron, and that's called being qualified (a seasoned professional, a qualified investor, a senior decision maker, etc), and being qualified is an important factor in the process of collective intelligence. As the other component besides diversity of background and perspectives. And qualification and diversity both feed each other, one can't exist productively without the other. However if that devolves into a sycophantic arrangement of technocratic expertise, that's where governance fails, and we see that a lot these days around us when confronted with planetary scale events and crises.

Currently the best source of information to make a voting decision is whatever is provided by the Catalyst Voting mobile app. The information provided in the app by each proposer goes through multiple rounds of revision by community advisors, which provides some rigor. But, ultimately there will be proposals on decisions that will require knowledge that is outside the scope of an individuals knowledge or abilities.
The currently proposed remedy is to all an individual to delegate their vote to an "expert" through a system of, "liquid democracy". However, the problem still stands...an individual may reason through the process along this line of reasoning, "I'm not informed enough to cast my own vote, how do I know how to delegate it to?" Whom is this individual to trust when making a decision about delegating their vote? Information provided by the "expert"? Is the expert trustworthy? The expert wants to win votes. The expert has incentive to say whatever is necessary to gain votes, be it truth or not.
A decentralized source of information that can be moderated and validated by the community, powered by the blockchain itself, would provide a trusted repository for individuals to reference. The source of information would bring concepts as complicated as network parameters and consensus mechanisms to the widest audience possible by breaking them down into relatable, manageable chunks of information. These explanations could be created by experts and teachers, validated by other experts, all of whom could be incentivized through a monetary rewards scheme, or a reputation system, for providing high quality and truthful information.

Choco, a solution for monetising online content.
The current options for content monetisation are, either centralised systems like Youtube or blockchain-based alternatives like MINDS, Odysee/LBRY etc. The problem of censorship resistance with centralised systems is well understood by most. Blockchain-based systems like MINDS or Odysee/LBRY address this problem but only for content hosted on their respective blockchains and platforms.
I am herewith submitting an idea on how to give creators the freedom to publish and monetise their content anywhere online, with minimal setup.
Let's say you have a blog that you want to monetise. Ideally, you want to have a "widget" for tipping that any user can press to send you some ADA (fixed or custom amount).
The way I am thinking this would work is:
A - There needs to be some sort of "back-end" server that receives the tip requests and broadcasts them to the blockchain. Ideally, the back-end server can be a wallet (Yoroi) on your client device (the sender). The tip requests are encoded as JSON-RPC.
B - The widget also supports an optional callback mechanism to send transaction data to the blog service provider.
C - We could also imagine a scenario where we have an interface between the widget and the wallet, a "mid-layer". The idea is, we may not always want to forward the tip requests directly to the wallet but through the mid-layer. The mid-layer would implement a set of business rules to help protect the wallet from abuse and have some reporting features.
To summarise, you have:

The presentation layer: A tip widget
The Business layer:
2.a) A controller, implemented by the blog service provider to handle the callback requests
2.b) The mid-layer
The persistence layer: The wallet
The data layer: the blockchain.

This should be implemented with customisation in mind. E.g. one should be able to customise the look and feel of the widget, also the data layer (Cardano for now, later, any other compatible blockchain) and/or currency (ADA or, later, any ADA ERC-720 token) for tipping. Additionally, anyone should be able to implement additional custom business rules on the mid-layer. Etc.

Blockchain becomes successful when it is used in ways that are impossible to do with fiat. ADA becomes dominant if it can do things no other blockchain can do. This proposal leverages ADA's stakepools and the incoming ability for holders to delegate their funds to multiple pools to provide charitable funding in a way not possible anywhere else.
Charitable funding has three major friction points to funding, tight pockets, government impositions, and the need for continual, reliable funding rather than funding in fits and starts. Lots of energy is spent dealing with these issues, rather than publicizing what is needed for a basic revenue stream.
Charitable giving also has some serious impositions. The first is a general desire to keep earned funds in our pockets, the second is dealing with government requirements about giving and reporting, and the third is a general lack of transparency.
The ADA garden alleviates all these friction points while enhancing the funding of charitable endeavors and decentralizing the blockchain.
In The ADA Garden, giving and receiving are made as easy as possible. The first barrier, tight pockets, is alleviated by not requiring anyone to actually reduce their balance to give to a charitable effort. It's far easier to donate a small fraction of your earning potential by delegating some of your stake than it is to dig around in your wallets, enter passwords, find addresses and send some amount when you happen to remember. All anyone has to do is delegate part of their funds to the charities they are interested in. Charities simply have to use this platform to set up those pools and describe their needs.
Government intervention is alleviated because donors do not actually send any funds anywhere, thus no reporting must be done regarding donations. The negative side effect of this is that tax write-offs will not be possible. However, this can be alleviated by also providing a one-stop place for ADA related charities. If people want to donate out of their funds directly, this will be possible too.
Transparency is what leads to trust and historically this is where charities often fail. Government enforced reporting leads to embellishments and vagaries regarding how funds are spent. With blockchain, every ADA can be tracked. Part of the charity profile will be describing how funds are spent, with addresses of vendors who will be accepting ADA as well as exchanges used to convert to fiat as needed, with time, the idea will be to reduce reliance on an exchange by having an ADA economy amongst the charity and its vendors and recipients. Our website will provide basic graphics describing the flow of funds.
Summary
Donating income potential is something that can only be done with a PoS blockchain. ADA is the only blockchain that can do this because the pools have extremely low funding thresholds required to start one, and will have the ability for people to delegate to multiple pools. Thus this idea promotes the use of blockchain and exemplifies one reason why ADA is better than other blockchains. The difference between the current state is summarized as follows

Donate earning potential in a set-it-and-forget-it method rather than acquired funds

 

As funds never leave your wallet, there is no reporting for donors even in the strictest government reporting scenario

 

As funds come by operating a pool, charities have a basic income they can rely upon rather than intermittent fund drives

 

Charities, using the ADA garden do not need strong technical skills as the platform will take care of the technical side of running pools

 

Charities will verify their recipients and vendors, thus every ADA can be accounted for at any time rather than vague reporting methods that are available only when the charity goes through the work of publishing them.

remarks:

It should be good to offer something that solves their problems. Some service/s that the Cardano infrastructure is well suited to solve for them, so that Cardano may become a key factor for their success and the base technology for their strategy. That could attract many users and developers to the ecosystem.
One of the main problems os software startups is to make an efficient use of the cloud. Cloud providers offer services like migration and scalability of the client services that are transparent, but are confined in the walls of the Cloud provider. Ouroboros is well suited to give some improvements to the market of cloud services in terms of transparency and fluidity.
Transparence in pricing: One of these improvements is to handle contracts and negotiation with different cloud providers, whose rates are now rather obscure and complex depending on the usage of many different parameters.
Fluidity and standardization: There is one more service that is also very important for distributing, migrating and escalating services: A fast registration and lookup of universal resource identifiers which are not locked in an specific cloud provider could make some central tasks of Cloud services much more open and standard. With this service, companies can migrate and scalate resources without be locked in the walls of a particular cloud provider. Names may collide, so they need a blockchain. At the same time, a change should be updated fast when new servers are added to the pool of the service, in terms of minutes, So DNS is too slow. Ouroboros can do it. That service could allow client programs to locate the address/addresses of the server/s so that a company can migrate and escalate their servers with far more ease, without the need to rely in the services of any particular cloud provider.
Having some library which provides name resolution and payment negotiation with cloud providers using Cardano infrastructure could be a great addition and attract many users and developers to the ecosystem.
 
Moreover, things do not end there. There are two possible strategies that depart from that naming+paying cloud services:
- To create a meta-provider of computer resources or…
- To create a cloud-provider independent standard for negotiating and migrating Cloud service agreements among clients and providers.

The gap between community and professional lobbyists is the same around the world where there is a huge bias in favor of the corporations. Technology can give us greater access to government but it is not being capitalized on by the community because of a lack of collaboration and the gap between government and community is growing bigger.
 
Community lobbying is a cycle of people rising up for an emotive issue, mostly under equipped to properly and professional lobby the government, they are mostly no match for what they are up against. Different groups and individuals lobbying for different issues come and go sometimes wasting mammoth efforts in campaigns that have little or no influence on government or legislation, they lack professionalism, experience and a realistic strategy to have any influence, the gap between community and special interests lobbyists is gargantuan.
Professional lobbyists reap sometimes massive financial rewards, while community lobbyists mostly pay from their own pocket and there are no financial rewards or personal recognition for their work, even when they are lobbying for all of our rights and freedoms.
The solution that I proposed creates an ecosystem that provides community lobbyists with tools that can help them professionally engage with the government and the tools for the broader community to better support them. Through a self sustaining application that incentivizes all stakeholders to get involved including government, this ecosystem can help reduce the gap between professional lobbyists and community lobbyists in their ability to raise money and expand their exposure and influence. This projects implementation also includes the engagement of government in the education and implementation of digital voting, a voting feature to be included in the application. There is also potential for government support or funding because all aspects of the application better serve the community and government.
The Cardano governance and consensus philosophies can be built into the foundations of this projects application with a treasury and consensus mechanisms, its adoption by default has the potential to educate the broader community about the Cardano decentralization philosophy, block chain, crypto currency and digital trust platforms.
A not for profit or fully decentralized application using Cardano philosophy would be the target management layer of this application. This application will be unique to every country and the statistical information from all countries could be collaborated to one website that will potentially create a wealth of information, examples, precedents and tools for everyone in the world to use.
Australia would be a good test case for this application because of our small population and our mandatory voting laws.

The Smart contracts functionality enabled by Plutus and Marlowe will allow developers to replicate the features of existing financial derivatives. While these Smart Contract Derivatives (SCDs) may be similar to the traditional derivatives, their underlying instruments will most likely be ADA or other crypto currencies and tokens.
SCDs with crypto underlyings maybe interesting for speculators and investors but if they can be connected to physical commodities, it would open up the possibility of individuals and small companies to buy DeFI SCDs for hedging purposes.
For example a small farmer would like to lock in the price of a crop of wheat or would like to fix their diesel costs for the year. This could be accomplished by buying a SCD Forward Contract on wheat or diesel.
These kinds of instruments are available already but only to very large companies who have relationships with Investment Banks. To make them available as DeFI SCDs, the Smart Contracts would need access to commodities market data that is trustworthy and reliable.
There are recognised sources of these market data in the traditional financial world. Examples are Reuters, Bloomberg, CME and many recognised and regulated market places.
The key point of this idea is to fund the development of market data gateways that interface with these trusted providers and act as Oracles in Cardano to provide inputs to the DeFI SCDs.
The availability of these data on the Cardano platform would open up an enormous DeFI market and democratise access to finance that is otherwise only available to large and connect companies and individuals.

The current gap allows for a few parties to "harvest" kudos throughout the Fund stages and deploy them on one project.
Fund stages approx timeline 8 weeks (~60 days)
4 parties would accumulate ~60 kudos each during a Fund timeline.
4 parties can deploy ~240 kudos on 1 project.
240 Kudos is currently = top 7 proposal (in the IMPACT portion of the ranking algo)
This can result in 4 parties artificially buoying a project to look "community-supported" in the eyes of a ranking algo.
This results in introducing skewed "community support" into a voting app that voters trust to be representative of a process that has undergone extensive scrutiny.
What we need is a better implementation of "kudos"
Maybe that comes with limitations? (IE: 4 kudos per account, per project, per fund)
Maybe that comes with conditions? (You must add a comment of at least 100 words as to why you left this Kudos)
Maybe that comes with account verifications? (Your account must have generated 5 comments of atleast 200 words before kudos can be allowed)
 
In essence, we need kudos to have a verifiable contributor and have controls in place to provide fairness.
If it belongs as part of the ranking algo, then it must start from a fundamentally sound architecture.
(People will rely on it as a source-of-truth when voting)

Currently, one can propose any amount of ADA requested.
It is my humble opinion that it would be to a great community benefit if there were an arbitrary ceiling imposed. For example, one proposal can ask for a maximum of 25% of total funds available for that given round.
We eliminate proposals that are too extreme relative to the overall fund size and focus more on manageable proposals instead.
The question would remain - what would be reasonable max ceiling rate per proposal and how would that be determined.
Additionally, it would seem to be a no brainer to me as the first step:

not allowing proposals to overdraft the fund treasury as a whole
aka one couldn't submit proposal that goes beyond 100% of the funds.

…as such extreme proposals defeat the whole purpose right out of the gate.
Let's discuss below why is this a good or bad idea. Curious as I haven't made up my mind just yet.
Cheers,
Daniel

When reviewing Proposals, I try and think about what it will look like inside the voting app, and how it will engage the voter. The Voting app displays these sections: Title, Problem Statement, Solution, Your Experience, (along with a link to read the proposal here in Ideascale, the Reviewer Ranking Score, and ADA Funding requirements).
As I go through the Proposals I find it very difficult to imagine that anyone voting will be able to make informed decisions based solely on the info found in the Voting App.
If they are required to create a login and then log into Ideascale, I see this as a barrier to voting. Probably a large barrier.
Two outcomes are immediately evident if the barrier to details is not lowered:

lower voter turnout
under-informed voting

I know that others have suggested that more info needs to be revealed in the Voting app. My first thought was that we want to keep the voting app data consumption as low as possible. And as such we don't want the entire Proposal there by default.
Is there any possibility of utilizing the Ideascale API, to allow for "pulling" the additional details into the voting app, only when requested by the user.
 
EDIT:
Dor has confirmed that the Voting app UI/UX will not change as we move into voting for Fund2. It will be the same look and feel as we had in Fund1.

THE PROBLEM:
The biggest problem today is that a vast amount of questions, and answers to those questions, are being iterated in Telegram, Discord, Facebook, and even in YouTUBE videos, that are not being indexed by Google, Bing and other search engines.
 
Many peculiar and interesting questions are not being trafficked on typical venues such as Reddit or the FAQs of IOHK and so on. Moreover, search queries via popular search engines can lead to a user having to troll through multiple resources to find the best answer to his or her search query.
 
THE SOLUTION:
Curate, nominate and create a repository of the best of those questions and answers on Cardanofaq.com.
Cardano FAQ's intentions is to be a community-driven curated set of best answers to frequently, and, importantly, not-so-frequently, asked questions. Also, and maybe more importantly, it raises the profile of the most authoritative voices and resources for the subject matter queried.
Curation addresses the issue of eliminating the need to troll enormous amounts of data on non-indexed resources like Telegram and Discord or to visit multiple answers to the same question across various social media platforms and web sites that cannot be indexed by the most popular search engines.
Curation also means referencing resources. Although answers to questions may be recreated on CardanoFAQ.com we also always add a list of links to the referenced original resource, with the permissions from the original authors if required, and in the case of original content, any citations.
Nomination is to propose references to resources and persons that are considered to be the most authoritative.
FAQs always include an easy to copy short URL of the answer that can be easily pasted into Telegram, Discord, and other commentary fields on sites such as YouTube and Facebook.

remarks:

I think many of us recognize and respond to the publicity that Cardano is already getting. One flavor of news that seems to get passed around a lot is breadth of Cardano's developmental progress. But as mentioned by institutional critics, our impact is yet to be recognized in full measure, not only because adoption is not complete, but because our use cases are not traditionally recognized yet. We need to make sure that projects now are intended for long term sustainable growth and are facilitating passive marketing in addition to active measures.
Think of this like SM influencers. The biggest ones do not create social impact on their own; there are many mid-level/low-level contributors that maintain attention in that space by constantly interacting with their own social groups (think Chainlink "marines"). So how do we not shoot ourselves in the foot with volatile SM? That means increasing the diversity of our outreach. BTC maximalists (proponents of a 11 year old project) constantly reach out to business leaders in loosely/unrelated sectors to build out the extensive discussion by exposition of real world problems and solutions, then intensify the discussion on where the money is coming from and going to. While Cardano does not have the first mover advantage, we do have the ability to learn from what the BTC maxis did in the past and what DeFi proponents are doing in the present.
Envisioned state includes such things as an actual English Wikipedia page (requires accepting wikipedia mods/admin), podcasts with popular public figures, and niche business sector involvement that coincides with Cardano's ability to create industry-specific DSL's.
project_definitions: Developer, Entrepreneur, Other/Prefer not to say

Even with insight into prior experience, it is hard to know whether someone will deliver successfully on their proposed plans. (I'm reminded of Malcolm Gladwell's essay, years back, about predicting the success of both teachers and NFL quarterbacks: https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2008/12/15/most-likely-to-succeed-malcolm-gladwell). With Project Catalyst, it is essential that we have some degree of confidence that a proposal has a chance to be successful, at the very least by delivering a return on its intention. Perhaps some sort of reputation metric can play a role in helping strangers decide if one another are up for a job, but even these metrics will be imperfect, and we must allow for capable newcomers to make great contributions.
Long term, lump sum fund dispersals will raise the stakes of needing to get it right as often as possible, and could lead either to wasted funds or gridlock in decision making. We should create mechanisms for proposers to submit funding plans in which milestones are met that trigger the release of more funds. The good news is that smart contracts and governance will facilitate the creation of these mechanisms.
One way to let the system take care of itself would be to encourage proposers to submit over time to successive funding rounds, but the drawback here would be similar to how politicians are always looking ahead to the next election. By building the right funding structure in advance, we can ensure that creators have maximum time to actually do the work they say they're going to do.

The current state: several proposals have proposed solid ideas related to attracting devs (i.e. dev marketplace, adamakerspace, dev education platform, dev hubs). Want to start by saying these ideas have all been GREAT and exactly what we need x100 of at this stage in my humble opinion. The problem is without a central location for all of these to exists for new Cardano devs the value proposition *in each of these* is diminished and the new dev is left bouncing from site to site as they navigate their specific needs. When you look at the current Gitcoin product lineup and the fact it's become the de facto developer meets entrepreneur Ethereum marketplace (~40k devs registered) it actually makes more sense for all of the Cardano dev/entrepreneur-centric proposals to merge ideas and create a central platform similar to Gitcoin composed of different products. I have attached as photos the Gitcoin lineup of products and a high level overview of the bounty product (I have mentioned this idea on multiple Project Catalyst group calls) which shows how a dev would receive payment for a project bounty posted by a "Funder". A similar contract for a dev bounty has been developed in Marlowe by a dev I believe Boone hired. You can see this here: https://youtu.be/sziNhvKEGI8?t=3029. This is one of several products I am proposing we pull into a central location to streamline the entire process for new Cardano devs.
 
Before I hit the future state you may be asking what actually is Gitcoin, here is a nice overview they give to answer the question "What is Gitcoin?":
Functionally, the app has several key features:
Smart Contracts -- Where funded issues are stored and indexed.
Brochureware -- Describes the project.
Funded Issue Explorer -- A searchable index of all of the work available in the system.
Funded Issue Submission / Acceptance flow -- Interface between the application and web3.
API - the HTTPS API
Bot - the GitcoinBot
Technically, the system is architected:
Web3 The main source of truth for the system is the Ethereum blockchain. Check out the smart contracts.
Web2 This part of the app is built with Python, Django, Postgres, and a handful of other tools that are common in the web2 ecosystem.
Web 3 Bridge This is the bridge between web3 and the rest of the application. Mostly built in javascript(web3js) and python(web3py).
Brochureware Just a nice little landing page telling folks what the Gitcoin project is.
 
Future state vision: A forked implementation of Gitcoin on Cardano,I refer to this as "Citcoin" would serve as the backbone for all things developer + project funder/proposer related. Keeping all of the main Gitcoin products and innovating where it makes sense (i.e. For the developer education component creating a product "Plutus Academy" as a training program to bring a new dev up to speed on Plutus development and output them with an intermediate/expert understanding of Plutus. The final assessment could involve them building and deploying a contract on mainnet and in the process mint an NFT certificate certifying them as a Plutus dev. Maybe their is certificate in addition to the NFT that goes to their Atala Prism ID). This is a simple example that touches various aspects of Cardano. from here if we talk about including governance components of Ideascale into Citcoin so that project funders can also play an early role in forming new project ideas before they reach a community vote/quorum. To take this one step further In it's final form Citcoin could completely encompass some form of early project idea governance (potentially even integrating some component of Ideascale for community members who want to be involved with the process of proposing project bounties/funding ideas!).
 
Steps involved to realize future state vision: https://github.com/gitcoinco
1. Hire a Python + JS + front-end dev to rebuild Gitcoin as a Cardano public utility for new developers.
2. We will also need to hire Haskell/Plutus devs capable of rebuilding the entire suite of smart contracts on Cardano rails (the bounty escrow smart contract has already been constructed in Marlowe, thanks to Boone and dev team)
3. Emurgo is currently working on a product that will allow for the web app to be accessible through a Yoroi wallet. This web 2.0 to web 3.0 bridge can *hopefully* be a simple process when they complete development for that integration.
 
Most of the smart contracts used by Gitcoin can be built in Marlowe. We can even dogfeed the bounty process to get devs building more complex Citcoin smart contracts and platform features (especially those related to developer education materials and the gamification process similar to the Gitcoin "Quests" product). Releasing an MVP followed by rapid iterations including dogfeeding the bounty feature to build out core product components is key to highlighting the platform's capabilities to new Cardano devs.
Please review this proposal and submit thoughts and ideas. I have a few devs I will begin tapping to gauge interest in this project and their may be even potential to *for a short time* poach a IOHK/Emurgo JS or front end devs to help with some of the UI/UX. Happy to hear any and all feedback :)

Can you articulate the gap between the current state and the expected or envisioned state?


Currently there exists no Process Outline which explains the steps required to Submit a Proposal to the Catalyst Project. This Current State does not provide any guidelines for discussions with a potential Proposer, concerning next steps and setting their expectations properly.
A clearly defined process would include information about timelines, resources, and systems used. This should start at How to Submit a Proposal all the way through reporting milestones of the proposal. (My opinion is: This should include reporting beyond the final launch and exit from the Funding process.)
